docs.lead_paragraph: Tommy G. Thompson, the new secretary of health and human services, said today that he would delay and reconsider rules that President Bill Clinton issued in late December to protect the privacy of people's medical records. Mr. Clinton described the rules as ''the most sweeping privacy protections ever written.'' They would affect virtually every doctor, patient, hospital, pharmacy and insurance plan in the country.

headline.main: Health Secretary Delays Medical Records Protections

docs.abstract: New Health and Human Services Sec Tommy G Thompson says he will delay and reconsider rules that Pres Clinton issued in late December to protect privacy of individual's medical records; health care industry has lobbied against rules as costly burden; Thompson photo (M)
docs.snippet: Tommy G. Thompson, the new secretary of health and human services, said today that he would delay and reconsider rules that President Bill Clinton issued in late December to protect the privacy of people's medical records.    Mr. Clinton described...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was 1993 when Katherine Russell Rich learned that her breast cancer had recurred. Tumors were eating away at her spine, and her doctors told her she was only weeks away from becoming both paralyzed and incontinent. As she lay curled in the fetal position in the hospital, groggy on morphine, a friend suggested that she hire a medical researcher to see what, if any, options were available. Clinical trials for new breast cancer treatments were out there -- but where? There was no central place to find them.

headline.main: Drug Trials Reach Out for Patients (and Vice Versa) on the Web

docs.abstract: Commerical Internet sites help match potential drug trial candidates with pharmaceutical companies; services, part matchmakers and part bounty hunters, are free to subjects and promise to cut down money pharmaceutical and biotech companies pay to find appropriate subjects; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Decade After Gulf War, Hussein's Hold Still Strong After the war to end Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, looked a finished man. But as Kuwait prepares to celebrate the 10th anniversary of its liberation, he is as firmly in power as ever. A1 Secretary of State Colin L. Powell met Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, in the second day of a trip aimed at shaping sharper sanctions against Iraq. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Governors' Association is proposing radical changes in Medicaid that would allow states to provide health insurance to millions of additional people, but the benefits would be less generous than those now guaranteed to poor people. Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland, a Democrat who is chairman of the association, said today that the new approach was needed because ''health care costs are rising at the same time tax revenues are declining in many states,'' and yet many governors want to help provide coverage to people who are uninsured.

headline.main: GOVERNORS OFFER 'RADICAL' REVISION OF MEDICAID PLAN

docs.abstract: National Governors' Association proposes radical changes in Medicaid that would allow states to provide health insurance to millions of additional people, but benefits would be less generous than those now guaranteed to poor people; plan would scrap current all-or-nothing structure of Medicaid, providing some access to basic health care for everyone, rather than a rich plan of health benefits for just a small group of people; Tommy G Thompson, secretary of health and human services, suggests that he supports governors' request for more freedom in operating Medicaid; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The National Governors' Association is proposing radical changes in Medicaid that would allow states to provide health insurance to millions of additional people, but the benefits would be less generous than those now guaranteed to poor people.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: For eight months, a court injunction barred restaurant workers at the Metropolitan Opera from criticizing the opera, but yesterday, with the injunction overturned, they faulted the Met for not intervening to make it easier for them to unionize. Speaking at a community forum four blocks from the opera house, the workers said they earned barely enough to support their families, and they called on the Met to pressure the contractor that runs its restaurants, Restaurant Associates, to agree to a streamlined way for them to unionize.

headline.main: Workers at Met Urge Opera to Intervene in Their Bid to Unionize

docs.abstract: Restaurant workers at Metropolitan Opera, saying they barely earn enough to support their families, want to join Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union; workers urge Met to pressure Restaurant Associates, contractor that runs its restaurants, to agree to streamlined way for them to unionize (M)
docs.snippet: For eight months, a court injunction barred restaurant workers at the Metropolitan Opera from criticizing the opera, but yesterday, with the injunction overturned, they faulted the Met for not intervening to make it easier for them to unionize.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: For nearly a century, Americans were able to retire at ever-younger ages and in greater prosperity. But over the last few years, they have begun staying on the job later into life. As companies cut pensions and retiree medical coverage, many aging employees doubt they can afford to retire, several experts and workers say.

headline.main: Reversing Decades-Long Trend, Americans Retiring Later in Life

docs.abstract: Percentage of Americans over 65 who still work has been rising since mid 1990's, reversing trend of nearly a century; erosion of pensions, health insurance and other retirement benefits is regarded as main reason, but other factors include tight labor makets, changes in Social Security system, ban on most forced retirements, economy's shift away from backbreaking jobs like those in mining and heavy manufacturing, and advances in medicine that allow people to work longer; many Americans are glad to be able to stay at their jobs, but for others it is not a matter of choice; graph; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For nearly a century, Americans were able to retire at ever-younger ages and in greater prosperity. But over the last few years, they have begun staying on the job later into life.    As companies cut pensions and retiree medical coverage, many aging...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the fight over legislation requiring insurers to cover contraceptives, the differences between the two sides are so sharp that a choice of words says it all. The Roman Catholic Church and its allies in the New York Legislature demand what they call a ''conscience clause,'' by which they mean that religious organizations opposed to birth control should be exempt from any law that mandates contraceptive coverage.

headline.main: Support for Health Care Bill Divided Over Contraception

docs.abstract: Roman Catholic Church and allies in New York State Legislature demand clause in legislation requiring insurers to cover contraceptives that would allow religious organizations opposed to birth control to be exempt from law that mandates contraceptive coverage; opponents say they will fight legislation containing exemption; fight threatens to hold up any agreement over large package of women's health measures (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MANY years ago, my wife's grandfather gave us a $5,000 municipal bond, which earns us about $350 a year in interest. Thanks, Grandpa. But I have been careless about clipping its coupons. Often, I wait until a bunch are due, then send them in all at once.
docs.abstract: James Schembari Midstream column on importance of keeping your financial paperwork in order, at least for the sake of those who will have to settle your affairs when you die; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN nature, bears hibernate in winter. But on Wall Street just now, it is hard to find many of them asleep. Pessimism and doubt have trumped irrational exuberance. Worries abound over corporate profits, stagflation and overleveraged consumers. Once clear and bright, the future of technology stocks is out of focus.

headline.main: What Brings A Bear Back to The Market

docs.abstract: Interview with Steve Leuthold, president of Leuthold/Weeden Capital Management, who has been a notable bear for years, but has lately started buying a lot of stock; photo (M)
